title: Can private schools replace public schools? - Quora

response.answer_text: So this is a tantalizing question for right wing pundits in the great U.S. of A. Wouldn’t it be great if we could shift the cost burden for education from all taxpayers to just those with kids in school, through privatization and vouchers (the latter of which wouldn’t completely shift away from all taxpayers sharing a little of the burden, of course, but it would substantially help, and it would, in their dream worlds, create competition where there is none and, I suppose, make all us lazy public school people get in gear with our hard-working private counterparts…?). None of that is true, of course. As a state employee I’ve been lucky to meet educators from public and private schools across the state, both affluent and high-poverty districts. Public school teachers aren’t lazy; private teachers aren’t somehow magically better than public teachers because they perceive any sort of competition. The classroom just plain doesn’t work that way. But the question — can private schools replace public schools? Sure, on the surface. Teaching is teaching. Public schools, the funding comes from public coffers, for which the public school must bear significant scrutiny, which is part of the reason public schools tend to have more admin staff than private schools do. Private schools bear no such scrutiny (and are thereby very much less accountable for methodology and results). But you’ll notice that there is no massive cry from private school organizations to have them replace public schools, right? You want to guess why that is? They know that at the end of the day, public schools must do something they do not: educate the public. That’s…all the public. It’s not just those who would self-select into private schools in the first place. It’s the kids coming from first generation American homes, the kids coming from poverty, the kids coming from abuse and neglect. It’s the kids who are academically way ahead of their peers, and those who are well behind. Nobody in the private school system wants that charge/burden. Nobody. Many in the public school system see that as our calling, our (almost) sacred charge…to take whatever the American communities send our way and shape those individually into successful high school graduates. But it is a burden, fiscal as well as emotional, and it’s not one that private schools are ready to take on.

Yes: Turn all public school funding into study credit reward money for students. Subsidize 100% of this curriculum: my answer to What are some things schools should teach but don't? Subsidize less important subjects less.(Consumption subsidy)Turn all public schools into private schools. (Privatization)Students buy each course from any school or home teacher of their choice. When they pass the course, they receive the study credit reward money and pay the course with it (if the price is less than the reward). Any extra price they pay out of pocket (or some percentage of exceeding price is subsidized to avoid causing market failure with a sharp cutoff). (Free market)Failing students/teachers (it’s a collaboration) receive a smaller subsidy. (Penal damage fee)Test result checking is separated from teaching to make passing everyone regardless of results impossible.(Separation of powers)Students rate the courses. Professional course evaluators do the same. Best rated course suppliers get popular, raise prices, and grow to serve more students. Bad schools and teachers stop getting new students and go out of business. Good schools fill the open opportunity.(Invisible hand)(Inspired by Finnish drug subsidies that can be used in any private pharmacy of your choice. Pharmacies decide their suppliers and pricing freely. Customers are free to vote with their feet.)

No. Private school teachers don't even have to be licensed. Public school teachers do. If public schools disappeared, tens of thousands of poor and disadvantaged children would be even worse off than they are now. And, a lot of those poor children would be left to their own devices. Their parents have to work. There would be no way they could afford private schools after rent, utilities, transportation, food, and insurance. Those kids would probably be running through the streets unsupervised causing chaos. Moreover, the children would be in grave danger of imminent harm from any number of things. From sex offenders, to fire hazards! When these kids grow up what kind of future do they face? There are almost no jobs for unskilled workers now! None that pay living wages anyway! Plus, it would just perpetuate the ruling class-private school educated people, against the servant class- non educated people! Sounds great huh?!

Can private schools replace public schools? Sure, they could. But then this would create a society where only the wealthy receive education. We’d then have a massive amount of illiteracy and and ignorance, and not enough people to do the jobs that our society needs. A huge welfare system would then have to be instituted, and these wealthy people would have to pay a enormous taxes to support the majority of the population who are too ignorant to support themselves.

If you decide that only certain classes of people need to be educated, sure, why not? By definition ‘private schools’ are paid for by the families that send their children to those schools. The idea that the state should sub contract out its responsibility to private businesses using public funds shouldn’t even be legal. Of course if you believe that the state has no function or responsibility to educate anyone then of course private schools would be required…. but not at public expense.

First, understand where the right to a public school education comes from; it comes from the constitution of each state. Education is not provided for in the United States Constitution. So, I suppose that citizens of a given state could decide that they no longer want to include a right to a public education in the state’s constitution, along with compulsory education laws, and there wouldn’t be a thing the federal government could do about it. But that would be kind of silly…

Not really. The only reason private schools have better scholastic results is that they can turn away low performing students. Public schools need to take everyone, even the emotionally disturbed or mentally retarded. If you make private schools accept everyone, they’ll give the same results as public schools, but cost more.
No.Many parents can not or will not pay the tuition.There are large regional differences in tuition due to supply and demand.OKC 10K a year including an afterschool program;LA area 30 - 45k.
No, and why would anyone want them to. They hold no advantage to the nation or any community over the public schools they already run.
No, in most state constitutions, the first role of government is to provide “free and appropriate public education.” Private schools don't meet this test.

Private schools should have access to the same taxed amount per student as public schools and they should compete. In my district, that is $11,500/student. Any student that wants to go to private or public school should get the $11,500 toward tuition.
